Award.AwardTitle: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Bayesian Modeling and Inference for Quantifying Terrestrial Ecosystem Functions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
While the past decade has seen considerable advances in predicting missing entries in data matrices, existing approaches have demonstrated sobering performance and several limitations in an important scientific problem: characterizing plant traits, such as plant height, seed mass, leaf area, and leaf nitrogen, over space and time. Detailed global maps of plant traits will enable accurate quantification of terrestrial ecosystem functions, such as agricultural and forest productivity, and regulation of atmospheric CO2 levels. This project uses the largest and most comprehensive plant trait database on the planet (TRY, www.try-db.org) to develop a detailed characterization of plant functional traits and trait diversity at relatively fine scales across most of the terrestrial land surface. In doing so, the project produces the first detailed uncertainty quantified maps of plant traits across all of earth's major land ecosystems as well as their future projections. The project trains a new generation of interdisciplinary scientists who can cross the traditional boundaries between computer science, spatial statistics, and the Earth sciences.

The research in the project makes substantial advances on Bayesian probabilistic models for matrix gap filling or matrix completion, as well as spatiotemporal gap filling with emphasis on continuous fields. In particular, the project develops probabilistic matrix completion models which can incorporate domain specific hierarchies, such as plant taxonomic or phylogenetic trees, as well as spatial variations across different environmental regimes. The project also develops methods for gap filling in continuous fields based on spatiotemporal process models along with highly scalable inference methods based on dynamic nearest-neighbor Gaussian processes. The models and methods are expected to have impact beyond the scope of quantifying ecosystem functions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grand vision at the core of this project is sustaining the world’s terrestrial ecosystems to maintain biodiversity and ecosystem functional services, such as agricultural and forest productivity, and regulation of atmospheric carbon dioxide levels. Realizing this vision will require substantial advances in our understanding of biodiversity, ecosystem processes and their vulnerability to climate change, and the feedbacks of ecosystems to the climate system, e.g., via the carbon cycle. Developing plans to promote environmental sustainability will be more feasible with a better understanding of future Earth. While climate system modeling has traditionally relied on the specification of future trajectories of greenhouse gas concentrations as an assumed forcing for prediction of future climate, over the past decade Earth system models (ESMs) have developed a capability to predict greenhouse gas concentration drivers directly. Unfortunately, the land surface component of modern ESMs parameterize vegetation with a small number of plant functional types (PFTs) with fixed attributes, which fails to capture the biodiversity at local and global scales.

An important component in realizing the aforementioned vision is the design, development and execution of data analytic tools for massive amounts of scientific data. The primary intellectual goals achieved by this project include the development of statistical methodologies, models and estimation algorithms for spatial-temporal BIG DATA, which refers to massive databases of geographically indexed scientific databases containing many years of data. The project has advanced intellectual growth in the fields of Bayesian statistics and machine learning for spatial-temporal databases. The project has also recognized the great value in developing open source software and creating associated learning material as a way to make methodological advances accessible to researchers in applied fields. To this end, the project has completed the development of two open source software packages designed for the R statistical computing environment. These products have attracted an international user base, and it is anticipated that subsequent releases will generate even more interest and provide further collaborative research and outreach opportunities. This software has served well in illustrating applied spatiotemporal statistics to varied audiences in several short course series administered by the team.

 The broader impacts of this project have begun to take effect, but will still take some time to fully fructify. Understanding terrestrial ecosystems to maintain biodiversity and ecosystem functional services, such as agriculture, forest productivity, and regulation of atmospheric carbon dioxide, is essential to a sustainable planet, especially under global climate change. The project will enable better quantification of relevant vegetation and ecosystem properties, which will be essential to reduce the uncertainties of climate-carbon cycle predictions and assess the vulnerability of vegetation under a changing climate. An important part of this proposal involves educational initiatives to engage students (including women and underrep-resented minorities). The project will train a new generation of interdisciplinary sustainability scientists
who can cross the traditional boundaries between computer science, spatial statistics and the Earth sciences. Building bridges between these communities will ultimately be not just mutually beneficial, but will also serve society at large. Results from the project will be disseminated through publications, tutorials, software, and course work.

As the scientific community is moving into a data-driven era, there is an unprecedented opportunity to enhance our understanding about how climate indicators change over time and space and how they will respond to changing environmental conditions. Although development of the proposed modeling frameworks are motivated by substantive questions in terrestrial ecosystems, the potential advancements in data modeling will be extremely useful in fields such as public and environmental health, meteorology, engineering, and geosciences where the fundamental goal is to use new findings to help improve society.
